name: Dittert conjecture
summary: The Dittert conjecture, also known as the Dittert–Hajek conjecture, is a mathematical hypothesis in combinatorics that states that a specific function, \(<<!nav>>\phi (X)=\prod r_{i}+\prod c_{j}-per(X)<<!/nav>>\), is uniquely maximized when the matrix \(X\) is the matrix \(J_{n}\), where all entries are equal to \(1/n\). This conjecture concerns \(n	imes n\) matrices with non-negative entries whose entries sum to \(n\), with \(r_{i}\) being the row sums, \(c_{j}\) being the column sums, and \(per(X)\) being the permanent of the matrix.
head: \(A\) is a matrix belonging to the defined set \(K_{n}\) (non-negative, entries sum to \(n\)).
